body_html:
Sorry for the delay on this. I've been trying for several days to compile from source so I could test it, but I seem to be down a rabbit hole where everything I do breaks something else. I first uninstalled the conda build of PyTorch, and after some effort (see #7764) managed to do that. Then I uninstalled the conda build of Caffe2 (probably a mistake) and tried to compile a consistent build of that from the same repository revision. That took quite a bit more effort (see #7770), but eventually I succeeded. Only then I couldn't get convert-onnx-to-caffe2 to work anymore. Eventually I decided that compiling Caffe2 had been a mistake, so I did my best to uninstall it (difficult, because it spews files all over the filesystem) and reinstalled the conda build. I was then able to convert my files. But somewhere in all of that, something else in my system has gotten broken. My C++ program that uses Caffe2 doesn't work anymore. When I run it, I get this error message:

ERROR: flag 'help' was defined more than once (in files '/opt/concourse/worker/volumes/live/26a9f68c-5f43-4c42-5672-33448f6eb48d/volume/gflags_1512755328973/work/src/gflags_reporting.cc' and '/tmp/gflags-20170916-46768-ftgkio/gflags-2.2.1/src/gflags_reporting.cc').

Needless to say, neither one of the files it's complaining about a conflict between actually exists on my computer...

Sorry for the delay on this.  I've been trying for several days to compile from source so I could test it, but I seem to be down a rabbit hole where everything I do breaks something else.  I first uninstalled the conda build of PyTorch, and after some effort (see #7764) managed to do that.  Then I uninstalled the conda build of Caffe2 (probably a mistake) and tried to compile a consistent build of that from the same repository revision.  That took quite a bit more effort (see #7770), but eventually I succeeded.  Only then I couldn't get convert-onnx-to-caffe2 to work anymore.  Eventually I decided that compiling Caffe2 had been a mistake, so I did my best to uninstall it (difficult, because it spews files all over the filesystem) and reinstalled the conda build.  I was then able to convert my files.  But somewhere in all of that, something else in my system has gotten broken.  My C++ program that uses Caffe2 doesn't work anymore.  When I run it, I get this error message:
ERROR: flag 'help' was defined more than once (in files '/opt/concourse/worker/volumes/live/26a9f68c-5f43-4c42-5672-33448f6eb48d/volume/gflags_1512755328973/work/src/gflags_reporting.cc' and '/tmp/gflags-20170916-46768-ftgkio/gflags-2.2.1/src/gflags_reporting.cc').

Needless to say, neither one of the files it's complaining about a conflict between actually exists on my computer...
body:
Sorry for the delay on this.  I've been trying for several days to compile from source so I could test it, but I seem to be down a rabbit hole where everything I do breaks something else.  I first uninstalled the conda build of PyTorch, and after some effort (see #7764) managed to do that.  Then I uninstalled the conda build of Caffe2 (probably a mistake) and tried to compile a consistent build of that from the same repository revision.  That took quite a bit more effort (see #7770), but eventually I succeeded.  Only then I couldn't get `convert-onnx-to-caffe2` to work anymore.  Eventually I decided that compiling Caffe2 had been a mistake, so I did my best to uninstall it (difficult, because it spews files all over the filesystem) and reinstalled the conda build.  I was then able to convert my files.  But somewhere in all of that, something else in my system has gotten broken.  My C++ program that uses Caffe2 doesn't work anymore.  When I run it, I get this error message:

```
ERROR: flag 'help' was defined more than once (in files '/opt/concourse/worker/volumes/live/26a9f68c-5f43-4c42-5672-33448f6eb48d/volume/gflags_1512755328973/work/src/gflags_reporting.cc' and '/tmp/gflags-20170916-46768-ftgkio/gflags-2.2.1/src/gflags_reporting.cc').
```

Needless to say, neither one of the files it's complaining about a conflict between actually exists on my computer...
